DRAFT
PRESIDENT * S COLUMN
I have attended a great many meetings of the NAEB Board of
Directors since I first became an officer of the organization in
19^9* By all odds, however, the best of these were the meeting
at the St* Louis convention on October 28, 29* and 30» and the
special meeting in Chicago on December 6, 7, and 8.
These sessions were devoted to the basic problems of educational
radio and television broadcasting* Naturally, any meeting of our
Board of Directors would be oriented around NAEB interests and activitiesj
yet, to me, one of the outstanding features of these talks was their
preoccupation with the overall problems of educational broadcasting,
rather than only with the status of NAEB*
At St* Louis we became increasingly aware of the emergence
of a new set of problems in educational broadcasting* At the same
time, we realized that it would be impossible to discuss these
adequately during our short time together, with so many routine matters
pressing for action, and with the Convention itself at hand*
Accordingly, we decided to hold a special meeting in Chicago on
December 6, 7 and 8, when we could address ourselves to the long¬
term problems*
One of the principal items on the agenda was educational
television* Here we are confronted by problems developing In
consequence of our earlier activities* NAEB was a leader in the
battle for the reservation of channels; tfe helped set up the
original Joint Committee on Educational Television (JCET); and we
were involved in the early planning for the Educational Television
and Radio Center (ETRC)*
